summary:
I am a campaigner, human rights specialist, and former academic with a broad interest in the world around me. Within the Clean Clothes Campaign network I fight for labour rights for and with garment workers and their unions. Before that I used to research human rights, peace, and solidarity in a Cold War and post-Cold War context, for which I used to travel to Poland and Germany and developed a strong network in and knowledge of those countries. Beyond that I support the struggle for human rights in Belarus and Ukraine through my voluntary work for Libereco. 

After studying history in Utrecht, Siena and Berlin I spent a year of volunteering for the organisations Press Now in Hilversum and the academic cultural centre of the University of Gdansk in Poland. Shortly afterwards I started my PhD research at the Institute for German Studies in Amsterdam. I always strived to combine my most important fields of interest: human rights, Central and Eastern Europe, migration, and sustainability. This I managed by volunteering for Amnesty International, Greenpeace, refugee organisations and the Youth Copenhagen Coalition beside my PhD research on Dutch and West-German leftwing organisations and the Polish opposition in the 1980s. After finishing my PhD I made the connection even closer by starting a follow-up research on Amnesty International and Poland and starting as campaign and outreach coordinator at Clean Clothes Campaign. In 2022, I spent five months volunteering at migrant rights and support organisations at the US-Mexican border. 

In my work I am enthusiastic and disciplined at the same time. From my academic career I take a propensity to be critical and analytical. As a campaigner I bring positive energy, creative thinking, and an ability to combine varying tasks. I am experienced in volunteer management, editing, communication, campaigning, lecturing, organising and research.

projects.title: Conferentie Mittler, Vervlechting, Netwerken. Duitsland en Nederland in de twintigste eeuw
projects.description:
De vijfde workshop van de WDNG in Amsterdam in september 2013 stelde zich ten doel de hoogte- en dieptepunten van de Duits-Nederlandse geschiedenis opnieuw te bekijken met aandacht voor dragers en mechanismen op en onder het politieke en diplomatieke niveau. Centraal stond daarbij het concept Mittler dat keynote speaker Nicole Colijn theoretisch toelichtte. In de anderhalve dag die daarop volgde passeerden vele praktische voorbeelden van vervlechting en Mittler tussen Nederland en Duitsland de revue, onder andere op het gebied van economische betrekkingen, kolonialisme en de tijd na de Koude Oorlog. In een postersessie kregen ook beginnende onderzoekers de kans hun projecten over Duits-Nederlandse betrekkingen te presenteren.

Ik was samen met mijn collega's voor de opzet van deze conferentie van opstellen van de Call for Papers tot de on the ground organisatie op de dag zelf.

profile_positions.description: Clean Clothes Campaign works to improve working conditions in the garment industry. As campaign and outreach coordinator I develop campaigns (worker safety, transparency, freedom of association, workers' rights violations) and coordinate public communication  (press releases, social media, website, newsletters).
profile_positions.title: Campaign and Outreach Coordinator

profile_positions.description: As a researcher at the Jena based Arbeitskreis Menschenrechte I analyse the dealings of the human rights organisation Amnesty International with and in Poland in the 1970s and 1980s, with special attention to the strains East-West controversies put on human rights work, as well as on initiatives in Poland society itself. This project is funded by the Germen Fritz Thyssen Stiftung.
profile_positions.title: Researcher (post-doc)

profile_positions.description: Lecturer for the history bachelor course 'Humanitarian Campaigns' about the development of humanitarian thinking and the human rights discourse from the 19th century until the present. Preparation of classes, grading papers, preparing and grading exams.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer

profile_positions.description: A grant of the German Historical Institute in Warsaw allowed me to work on a project of the Polish Institute for National Rememberance regarding the political activity of Polish emigrants in the Netherlands.
profile_positions.title: Guest Researcher

profile_positions.description:
The rise of Solidarność in Poland in 1980 confronted the Western European with some difficult anxieties, doubts and dilemmas. The most important of those was the question whether one should show solidarity with the Polish workers by making human rights demands or whether the Western European and Polish situation was better served by emphasising the importance of peace and détente. In the Federal Republic and the Netherlands the peace issue was very high on the political agenda, with several 100.000s protesting on the streets in Bonn and Amsterdam during 1981. At the same time the Federal Republic had a high stake in détente policy, because of its exceptional geopolitical position in Europe. Especially the left-wing movements in these countries were therefore torn between their traditional international solidarity with workers and freedom struggle as well as their current concern for peace and détente in what would be called ‘the second Cold War’.

In my research the focus is on the peace movement - as one of the main societal actors in these years and the protectors of ‘peace’ -, the labour movement - as the most obvious partner for Solidarność -, and social democracy, as the inventors and guarders of détente. By studying the debates and actual activity of these organisations on Solidarność, I will try to answer the question how the emergence of Solidarność affected their world view and which choice they made in the solidarity/détente dilemma. Special attention will be paid to the East-West dialogue from below that thrived in the 1980s and in which the Polish developments played a crucial role. Direct contacts with Poland and other Eastern European countries showed that the opposition did not share the Western European concern for peace and détente and thereby questioned the validity of the dilemma the Western Left struggled with too vehemently.

See my book at http://nl.aup.nl/books/9789056297633-vrede-of-vrijheid.html

volunteer_experiences.role: Human rights activism and humanitarian support work
volunteer_experiences.description:
As active member of the small human rights NGO Libereco, focused on human rights in Belarus and Ukraine, I participated in preparing a human rights monitoring report (2016) a campaign focused on students expelled from university (2017), ongoing fundraising for war relief in Ukraine, ongoing campaigns for the release of political prisoners & against repression in Belarus, with special intensity around and after the rigged elections of August 2020, and solidarity and support work for our partners on the ground in Ukraine after the Russian invasion in February 2022. I am a member of the German board and Libereco representative in the Netherlands since 2022.
Read more on www.libereco.org.

As voluntary coordinator for Eastern Europe, especially Ukraine, Belarus and Poland, I functioned as the specialist to turn to within Amnesty Netherlands on these countries. I was involved in preparing lobby, public campaigns and other activities on these countries and assist in answering questions from the public and organising visits of activists from the region. I also managed the activity of local groups working on these countries.
I was involved in instigating and organising a range of campaigns, events and activists' visits including the 2013 event "four weeks for freedom", focusing on the release of Belarusian Human Rights activist Ales Bialiatski, the 2014 visit of former Belarusian presidential candidate Andrei Sannikov to the Hague and Amsterdam and the 2015 campaign "Sky4Statkevich", followed by the release of former Belarusian presidential candidate Mikalai Statkevich, and the year long campaign for the three women accused of spreading posters that hurt the feelings or religious people in Poland in 2021.

I supported the functioning of a health clinic and shelter outreach for refugees in Tijuana at the US border who seek asylum in the US. Tasks included file management, handling medicine, taking vitals, etc.

Cooking, serving and delivering skipped/donated/saved food for a donation or for free to people in need of food.  Food pick-ups from shops, delivery at shelters and solidarity fridge. Between May-September 2022 volunteering at Comida No Bombas (Food Not Bombs) Tijuana, Mexico.
Homework support and personal buddy at this shelter for undocumented women and children. Exchange and participation in buddy meetings.

volunteer_experiences.role: Museum guide, Food Delivery, Children's Playmate
volunteer_experiences.description: Supporting activities for asylum seekers and recent status holders in Utrecht by accompanying museum visits, delivering food and supporting children's activities.

volunteer_experiences.role: representative of the Dutch Youth Copenhagen Coalition to the COP15
volunteer_experiences.description:
The Youth Copenhagen Coalition represented 14 Dutch youth organisations. In the months before the Copenhagen climate conference it prepared public actions to ask attention for this subject. In Copenhagen the Coalition tried to get as much attention possible for the opinions of young people about the issues at stake.
